CANVAS REDESIGN

  • HTML
  • SASS
  • 11ty

FALL 2020 / SUMMER 2021

PROCESS

01 / 06

SYNOPSIS

Started as a part of my UI/UX class at MICA, the goal of this project was to redesign Instructure's Canvas in order to create a learning management system focused on overall clarity and organization, as well as intuitive use for both students and instructors.

Redesign home page

PROCESS

02 / 06

PROBLEMS

Through 5 interviews with students using Canvas (in fall of 2020), I boiled down the main problems with the current system to 3 main items:

  1. Disorganized and varying class structures → Syllabus locations differ between classes
  2. Too many options for students to click through in order to get to their destination
  3. Not intuitive → Students must spend time on each individual class site in order to figure out navigation for that specific class

SOLUTIONS

As a result, I decided to focus on 3 main ideas in order to create a learning management system that can aid students' work-flow while also allowing instructors to setup their classes intuitively and with similar organization schemes:

  1. Simplicity in options → pare down all current options to only the bare essentials
  2. Consistent organization between classes for both students and instructors
  3. Ease of use, intuitive use, as well as efficient use → Students should not have to spend more time on the site than needed so that their work-flow is not interrupted

PROCESS

03 / 06

SITE MAP 1

After running card sorting with the same interviewees, the first hierarchical solution that I came up with split the content into three main categories:

  1. Agenda
  2. Class Information
  3. Profile

The 'agenda' category gathers general yet relevant class information and presents it in a meaningful way so that students don't have to go digging to find assignment information for a project due the next week. The 'class information' category is for specific assignments and modules as well as grades and previous class content, while the 'profile' category serves as an overall settings, preferences, and class history for the student.

First site map

PROCESS

04 / 06

SITE MAP 2

After tree testing 5 scenarios involving the same interviewees, I decided to further reduce the 'class information' options because there seemed to be confusion as to where certain items were located. Only 6 categories remained within 'class information':

  1. Class Home
  2. Assignments
  3. Modules
  4. Class Calendar
  5. Syllabus
  6. Grade
Second site map

PROCESS

05 / 06

PROTOTYPES

First low fidelity prototype using html and css

Second low fidelity prototype using html and css

PROCESS

06 / 06

FINAL RESULT

→ GOING FORWARD

After prototyping with simple html and css, the final redesign was created using html and sass within 11ty.

Although the site is responsive and works on mobile, the individual class navigation requires a collapsing menu, and as a result, I opted to leave the nav bar as is because I wanted to focus on the site hierarchy and overall design. Going forward, I plan to implement a collapsing menu for both the whole site navigation as well as for the individual class sites.

SEE FULL SITE →
Final result — 'class home'
